importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky earned international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in November 2007, establishing himself as one of the country’s most promising young talents.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, marking a significant milestone in his career as a public chess commentator and educator.
The 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis opened with a moment of silence for Naroditsky, indicating his lasting impact on the current chess community and events.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2025 captures Naroditsky’s rise from youth championship success to becoming a globally influential chess educator, commentator, and online figure.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He was born and raised in the San Francisco Bay Area and earned the title of grandmaster before high school.
Naroditsky won multiple grade-level national championships, including becoming the youngest player to win the California K-12 Championship at age 10.
He earned international acclaim in 2007 as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion.
He graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
He authored a chess manual at age 14 and became a regular contributor to Chess Life magazine and the New York Times as a chess columnist.
He built massive online followings on YouTube (nearly 500,000 subscribers) and Twitch (340,000 followers), livestreaming games and teaching accessible chess strategies.
He served as a head coach at the Charlotte Chess Center in Charlotte, North Carolina.
The International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his death, praising him as a talented player, commentator, and educator.
The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor, highlighting his influence on the current chess community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a 29-year-old American chess grandmaster from the San Francisco Bay Area, died unexpectedly. He earned the grandmaster title before high school and gained international recognition as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in 2007. After attending Stanford University and earning a degree in history, he became a prominent chess educator and commentator, contributing to Chess Life and the New York Times. His online presence—nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers—helped make chess accessible and engaging for a global audience. As a head coach at the Charlotte Chess Center, he influenced both students and the broader chess community. The International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his death, and the 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor, underscoring his lasting legacy as a passionate educator and innovator in modern chess culture.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
